projectName: FINAL EVALUATION OF THE UNDP/GEF PROJECT EGY/99/G35 - Introduction of Vehicle Electric Bus Technology and Hybrid-Electric Bus Technology in Egypt - Phase 1a
Introduction of Viable Electric and Hybrid-Electric Bus Technology in Egypt
projectDetail: The project involved the introduction of electric and hybrid-electric bus technology in Egypt, specifically focusing on testing 24 electric buses in historic sites. The project aimed to reduce air pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, and promote sustainable transportation. Phase 1a involved testing two buses, with plans for further phases that were not realized due to funding issues. The project provided valuable insights into the operation and maintenance of electric buses in Egypt.

The project aimed to introduce viable electric, hybrid-electric, and eventually fuel cell technology for buses in Egypt. It involved testing 24 electric buses in historic sites, training transportation managers, and developing plans for local manufacturing of electric drive systems. Phase 1a tested two buses, with plans for Phase 1b to test 22 more. However, follow-up phases were not realized due to funding issues. Recommendations included exploring alternative financing, awarding concessions for bus operation, and expanding electric bus usage in downtown areas. Lessons learned included the need for adaptation to local conditions and the importance of technical training.

The project is an evaluation of the UNDP/GEF project in Egypt focused on clean buses technology. The evaluation aims to assess project results, impacts, sustainability, and lessons learned. The final report will include an executive summary, project context, key findings, recommendations, lessons learned, and annexes. The evaluation will be conducted by an independent international expert with qualifications in climate change, project evaluation, and familiarity with GEF rules. The methodology will include documentation review, interviews, field visits, and data analysis. The report should not exceed 50 pages and will be submitted within 2 weeks of the mission. Stakeholders include UNDP Egypt, Ministry of Environment, Social Fund for Development, and Supreme Council of Antiquities.

[Project Detail]
The project involves the introduction of electric buses in Egypt, with Phase 1 split into sub-phases for trials. Unexpected issues arose during testing, leading to lessons learned for future phases. Collaboration with industry associations and stakeholder participation were key aspects. Financing for follow-up phases may come from Egyptian sources, with a concession model proposed for bus operation. Challenges included technical problems and negotiations with suppliers.
theme: Introduction of Vehicle Electric Bus Technology and Hybrid-Electric Bus Technology, Urban Air Pollution, Sustainable Transportation, Environmental Impact, Health Impact, Economic Feasibility, Technology Adoption, Public Transportation, Greenhouse Gas Emissions, Operation and Maintenance, Local Manufacturing, Funding and Financing.
Promoting electric and hybrid-electric bus technology in Egypt.

donor: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) with financial support from the Global Environment Facility (GEF)
contribution: The contributions made to the project include testing two electric buses, training local technical staff, conducting environmental and socio-economic impact analysis, and providing insights into the acquisition, operation, and maintenance of electric buses.

The contributions made to the project include seeking assistance from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) with financial support from the Global Environment Facility (GEF), testing 24 electric buses in Phase 1, training local technical staff, conducting environmental and socio-economic impact analysis, and providing recommendations for future phases of the project.
The contributions made to the project include progress assessment, recommendations for sustainability, lessons learned, best practices, and development of further project proposals.
